subcategories.title: Introduction to Complex Numbers
subcategories.content:
Introduction to Complex Numbers

Complex numbers extend the real number system to solve equations that have no real solutions, such as $x^2 + 1 = 0$.

A complex number is expressed in the form: $$z = a + bi$$ where:

  • $a$ is the real part (Re(z))
  • $b$ is the imaginary part (Im(z))
  • $i$ is the imaginary unit where $i^2 = -1$

subcategories.title: Basic Operations
subcategories.content:
Basic Operations

Addition and Subtraction

$$(a + bi) + (c + di) = (a + c) + (b + d)i$$ $$(a + bi) - (c + di) = (a - c) + (b - d)i$$

Multiplication

$$(a + bi)(c + di) = ac + adi + bci + bdi^2 = (ac - bd) + (ad + bc)i$$

Division

To divide complex numbers, multiply numerator and denominator by the complex conjugate of the denominator: $$\frac{a + bi}{c + di} = \frac{(a + bi)(c - di)}{(c + di)(c - di)} = \frac{(ac + bd) + (bc - ad)i}{c^2 + d^2}$$

subcategories.title: Complex Conjugate
subcategories.content:
Complex Conjugate

The complex conjugate of $z = a + bi$ is denoted as $\overline{z} = a - bi$.

Properties:

  • $z + \overline{z} = 2a$ (real)
  • $z - \overline{z} = 2bi$ (imaginary)
  • $z \cdot \overline{z} = a^2 + b^2$ (real and positive)

subcategories.title: Geometric Representation
subcategories.content:
Geometric Representation

Complex numbers can be represented as points in the complex plane (Argand diagram):

  • x-axis: real part
  • y-axis: imaginary part

Polar Form

$$z = r(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta) = re^{i\theta}$$ where:

  • $r = |z| = \sqrt{a^2 + b^2}$ (modulus)
  • $\theta = \arg(z)$ (argument)
Visual representation of complex numbers in the complex plane

subcategories.title: Euler's Formula
subcategories.content:
Euler's Formula

$$e^{i\theta} = \cos\theta + i\sin\theta$$

This leads to the beautiful identity: $$e^{i\pi} + 1 = 0$$

subcategories.title: De Moivre's Theorem
subcategories.content:
De Moivre's Theorem

For any integer $n$: $$[r(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta)]^n = r^n(\cos n\theta + i\sin n\theta)$$

This theorem is useful for:

  • Finding powers of complex numbers
  • Finding roots of complex numbers
  • Solving trigonometric identities

subcategories.title: Applications
subcategories.content:
Applications

Complex numbers are essential in:

  • Electrical engineering (AC circuit analysis)
  • Quantum mechanics (wave functions)
  • Signal processing (Fourier analysis)
  • Control theory (system stability)
  • Fluid dynamics (potential flow)

subcategories.title: Example Problems
subcategories.content:
Example Problems

Example 1: Basic Operations

Simplify $(2 + 3i) + (4 - 5i)$

Solution: $$(2 + 4) + (3 - 5)i = 6 - 2i$$

Example 2: Multiplication

Find $(1 + 2i)(3 - 4i)$

Solution: $$= 1\cdot3 + 1\cdot(-4i) + 2i\cdot3 + 2i\cdot(-4i)$$ $$= 3 - 4i + 6i - 8i^2$$ $$= 3 + 2i + 8 = 11 + 2i$$

Example 3: Division

Simplify $\frac{3 + 4i}{1 - 2i}$

Solution: Multiply numerator and denominator by the conjugate $(1 + 2i)$: $$= \frac{(3 + 4i)(1 + 2i)}{(1 - 2i)(1 + 2i)} = \frac{3 + 6i + 4i + 8i^2}{1 + 4} = \frac{-5 + 10i}{5} = -1 + 2i$$

Example 4: Polar Form

Convert $z = 1 + i$ to polar form

Solution: $r = \sqrt{1^2 + 1^2} = \sqrt{2}$ $\theta = \arctan(1/1) = \frac{\pi}{4}$ So $z = \sqrt{2}(\cos\frac{\pi}{4} + i\sin\frac{\pi}{4}) = \sqrt{2}e^{i\pi/4}$

subcategories.title: Practice Exercises
subcategories.content:
Practice Exercises

  1. Simplify $(2 - 3i)^2$
  2. Find the complex conjugate of $5 - 2i$
  3. Convert $z = -2 + 2i$ to polar form
  4. Solve $z^2 + 4 = 0$ in the complex number system
  5. Find all cube roots of $8$

subcategories.title: Key Properties
subcategories.content:
Key Properties

  • Complex numbers form a field (closed under addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division)
  • The complex number system is algebraically closed (every polynomial has a root)
  • Complex numbers obey the commutative, associative, and distributive properties
